title: 111_s2784
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The unified credit against gift tax is amended to remove the $1,000,000 exclusion amount. The exclusion equivalent of the unified credit against estate tax is set at $3,500,000. The estate tax dollar amount for decedents dying after 2010 is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The maximum estate tax rate is set at 45 percent. The estate tax dollar amount for decedents dying after 2010 is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The maximum estate tax rate is set at 45 percent. Amendments are made to section 2102(b) of the Code regarding the applicable credit amount and the treatment of residents of possessions of the United States. Modifications are made to the estate and gift taxes to reflect differences in unified credit resulting from different tax rates. The estate tax computation is amended to use modifications described in subsection (g) instead of subsection (c) at the decedent's death. Additionally, gift tax payable is adjusted to reflect different tax rates in effect at the decedent's death. Modifications are made to the estate and gift taxes to reflect differences in unified credit resulting from different tax rates. The gift tax section is amended to use rates of tax in effect for the current calendar year instead of preceding periods when determining the credit amounts allowable. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying, generation-skipping transfers, and gifts made after December 31, 2009. Additionally, certain provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 related to estate tax are repealed, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is to be applied as if those provisions had never been enacted. The Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is amended to not apply after December 31, 2010. Sections 2011, 2057, and 2604 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are repealed. SEC. 2. Unified credit increased by unused unified credit of deceased spouse. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include new paragraphs regarding the applicable exclusion amount and basic exclusion amount for tax purposes. The basic exclusion amount is set at $3,500,000 and will be adjusted for inflation for decedents after 2010. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include new paragraphs regarding the applicable exclusion amount and basic exclusion amount for tax purposes. The basic exclusion amount is set at $3,500,000 and will be adjusted for inflation for decedents after 2010. The term 'aggregate deceased spousal unused exclusion amount' is defined as the lesser of the basic exclusion amount or the sum of deceased spousal unused exclusion amounts. The term 'deceased spousal unused exclusion amount' is defined as the excess of the basic exclusion amount of the deceased spouse for surviving spouses of those who died after December 31, 2009. The deceased spousal unused exclusion amount can be utilized by a surviving spouse only if the executor files an estate tax return and makes an irrevocable election. No election can be made if the return is filed after the prescribed time limit. The IRS can examine a deceased spouse's return to determine the unused exclusion amount after the time limit for assessment has expired. Regulations will be prescribed for this purpose. Amendments are made to sections of the Internal Revenue Code to reflect these changes. The IRS can examine a deceased spouse's return to determine the unused exclusion amount after the time limit for assessment has expired. Regulations will be prescribed for this purpose. Amendments to sections of the Internal Revenue Code change "applicable exclusion amount" to "basic exclusion amount" effective for estates of decedents dying, generation-skipping transfers, and gifts made after December 31, 2009. The Senate believes that any decrease in Federal revenues from this Act should be fully offset.
